claim: Myanmar traditional medicine can cure the coronavirus.
label: FALSE

claim: Argentinian doctor Mühlberger has the cure against COVID-19
label: FALSE

claim: A Facebook post shared thousands of times claims that Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered Covid-Organics, a herbal drink touted by Madagascan President Andry Rajoelina as a cure for COVID-19. The post claims that Putin urged Africans “not to follow” the World Health Organization (WHO), which has warned against untested traditional medicine.
label: FALSE

claim: Some websites claimed that Madagascar quit the World Health Organisation (WHO) and has been offered 20 million dollars by the WHO to kill their Covid-Organics cure.
label: FALSE

claim: A video shows healthcare professionals in a hospital displaying hopeful message. The caption states the video was filmed at Moinhos de Vento Hospital, in Porto Alegre, Brazil, and that they managed to cure all the COVID-19 patients in their ICU and were, thus, celebrating.
label: FALSE

claim: Boldo tea can cure COVID-19 in three hours.
label: FALSE

claim: Kozhikode District Magistrate audio clip claiming steam, saltwater gargling and drinking herbal tea can cure/resist COVID-19.
label: FALSE

claim: A Facebook page uploaded an interview with a man who supposedly got cured of COVID-19 through salt water steam inhalation therapy, and told readers the answer is “not a vaccine but salt.”
label: FALSE

claim: “Hydroxychloroquine cures this ‘virus.’ It just so happens this is the treatment used for radiation sickness!!”
label: FALSE

claim: Palm oil is a simple cure for the coronavirus.
label: FALSE

claim: Green or black tea with lemon and two spoons of fennel flower cures COVID-19.
label: FALSE

claim: By drinking Ayurvedic decoction, 6 thousand corona infected patients were cured.
label: FALSE
